title: How to Make a Clothesline to Use Without Hangers

steps.headline: Find the smallest, thinnest surgical tubing you can find.
steps.description: If not surgical tubing, you can use some form of long rubber band. If you can't find something like these, buy a box of the heavy gauge rubber bands that the post office uses around bundles of mail. You will want about 20 feet (6.1 m) of the item in it's unstretched condition. You will need two small gate hooks from any hardware store, too. (See tips below.)

steps.headline: If you use rubber bands you will first have to loop the bands together by putting one through another and back through itself before it's pulled tight.
steps.description: By linking these together you will end up with a long stretchy band of continuous rubber bands.

steps.headline: Once you have the full length you need (about 20 ft.) divide it into 3rds and cut it into separate pieces.
steps.description: Tie one end of all three strands into a knot so it ends up looking like three strands of spaghetti hanging from your hand.

steps.headline: String one of the hooks along one of the strands until it's next to the knot.
Begin to braid the three strands in a common overlap pattern.
steps.description: This is what you may have learned in elementary school. You know, lay them side by side and take the left one over the middle one to become the middle one and then take the right one over the middle one to make a new middle one. Keep repeating this process until the entire length is braided. Don't do it too loose or real tight. You might want to experiment a little before the next step.

steps.headline: Once you're satisfied with the braided strands, Put the second hook in one of the strands.
steps.description: Tie off the final end by wrapping it in strong string, wire, several twist-ties, or something that will keep if from unraveling, or simply tie them in a knot again.

steps.headline: It's ready to use almost anywhere, anytime, without hangers, clothespins or hanging things over the line.
Loop each end around some fixtures so the entire line is slightly stretched.
steps.description: It should be about 6 feet (1.8 m). long when up.

steps.headline: When you go to hang anything, pull one of the strands away from the other two and place a small corner of the garment through the gap.
steps.description: For example you can take the bottom hem of a shirt and put a small part through the braided strands then take another part of the bottom hem on the other side of the shirt and do the same thing further down the line.

text: Find the smallest, thinnest surgical tubing you can find. If not surgical tubing, you can use some form of long rubber band. If you can't find something like these, buy a box of the heavy gauge rubber bands that the post office uses around bundles of mail. You will want about 20 feet (6.1 m) of the item in it's unstretched condition. You will need two small gate hooks from any hardware store, too. (See tips below.) If you use rubber bands you will first have to loop the bands together by putting one through another and back through itself before it's pulled tight. By linking these together you will end up with a long stretchy band of continuous rubber bands. Once you have the full length you need (about 20 ft.) divide it into 3rds and cut it into separate pieces. Tie one end of all three strands into a knot so it ends up looking like three strands of spaghetti hanging from your hand. String one of the hooks along one of the strands until it's next to the knot.  Begin to braid the three strands in a common overlap pattern. This is what you may have learned in elementary school. You know, lay them side by side and take the left one over the middle one to become the middle one and then take the right one over the middle one to make a new middle one. Keep repeating this process until the entire length is braided. Don't do it too loose or real tight. You might want to experiment a little before the next step. Once you're satisfied with the braided strands, Put the second hook in one of the strands. Tie off the final end by wrapping it in strong string, wire, several twist-ties, or something that will keep if from unraveling, or simply tie them in a knot again. It's ready to use almost anywhere, anytime, without hangers, clothespins or hanging things over the line.  Loop each end around some fixtures so the entire line is slightly stretched. It should be about 6 feet (1.8 m). long when up. When you go to hang anything, pull one of the strands away from the other two and place a small corner of the garment through the gap. For example you can take the bottom hem of a shirt and put a small part through the braided strands then take another part of the bottom hem on the other side of the shirt and do the same thing further down the line.
